channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: White House defends its 'Fork in the Road' offer to federal employees
item.description: The White House says the federal employees union is doing its members a disservice by urging them not to resign with the promise of administrative leave until September.
item.content:encoded:
The White House says the federal employees union is doing its members a disservice by urging them not to resign with the promise of administrative leave until September.

(Image credit: Kevin Dietsch)
item.dc:creator: Franco Ordoñez

item.title: Elon Musk is barreling into government with DOGE, raising unusual legal questions
item.description: The billionaire's campaign to radically upend federal agencies is stunning former White House officials, even in a political moment when many things are described as unprecedented.
item.content:encoded:
The billionaire's campaign to radically upend federal agencies is stunning former White House officials, even in a political moment when many things are described as unprecedented.

(Image credit: Chip Somodevilla)
item.dc:creator: Bobby Allyn

item.title: Federal judge issues restraining order blocking federal spending freeze
item.description: The order came in response to a memo released by the Office of Management and Budget last week directing agencies to freeze funding for federal grants and other programs.
item.content:encoded:
The order came in response to a memo released by the Office of Management and Budget last week directing agencies to freeze funding for federal grants and other programs.

(Image credit: Jim Watson)
item.dc:creator: Elena Moore

item.title: Super Bowl ticket prices have been falling, and are down by thousands from last year
item.description: Ticket prices have been dropping over the past few days and many tickets are selling for thousands of dollars less than a year ago.
item.content:encoded:
Ticket prices have been dropping over the past few days and many tickets are selling for thousands of dollars less than a year ago.

(Image credit: Godofredo A. Vásquez)
item.dc:creator: Juliana Kim

item.title: Trump plans to withdraw the U.S. from the United Nations Human Rights Council
item.description: The president's executive order will also cut future funding to the United Nations Relief and Works Agency, which provides aid to Palestinians.
item.content:encoded:
The president's executive order will also cut future funding to the United Nations Relief and Works Agency, which provides aid to Palestinians.

(Image credit: Oliver Contreras)
item.dc:creator: Deepa Shivaram

item.title: Jail Goodwill store offers job training and a new look on the way out
item.description: At the Elmwood Correctional Facility in Milpitas, Calif., incarcerated women organize and run a Goodwill store, where women nearing release get to shop for clothing.
item.content:encoded:
At the Elmwood Correctional Facility in Milpitas, Calif., incarcerated women organize and run a Goodwill store, where women nearing release get to shop for clothing.

(Image credit: Brian Krans)
item.dc:creator: Brian Krans

item.title: The people and the waterway at the center of the Panama Canal
item.description:
The Panama Canal has sat at the center of global trade for more than a century, connecting two oceans. The things Americans use every day pass through here, from gas to food. And now, this spot is also at the center of President Trump's global expansionist agenda.

Secretary of State Marco Rubio has just wrapped up a trip to Panama where he told the President that if China's influence over the canal isn't curbed the United States will take measures to protect its rights.

Trump's threat to take back the Panama Canal has the potential to reshuffle global politics. We're meet the people and the 51-mile waterway in the middle of it all.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org

Email us at considerthis@npr.org
item.content:encoded:
The Panama Canal has sat at the center of global trade for more than a century, connecting two oceans. The things Americans use every day pass through here, from gas to food. And now, this spot is also at the center of President Trump's global expansionist agenda.

Secretary of State Marco Rubio has just wrapped up a trip to Panama where he told the President that if China's influence over the canal isn't curbed the United States will take measures to protect its rights.

Trump's threat to take back the Panama Canal has the potential to reshuffle global politics. We're meet the people and the 51-mile waterway in the middle of it all.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org

Email us at considerthis@npr.org

(Image credit: MARK SCHIEFELBEIN)

item.title: ACLU sues Trump administration over asylum ban
item.description: The lawsuit alleges Trump's actions go against protections provided by Congress and backed by the courts.
item.content:encoded:
The lawsuit alleges Trump's actions go against protections provided by Congress and backed by the courts.

(Image credit: Alex Brandon)
item.dc:creator: Sergio Martínez-Beltrán

item.title: Trump pauses tariffs on Canada and Mexico. Here's why it matters to automakers
item.description: The auto industry has built a North American supply chain that ping-pongs parts between the U.S., Mexico and Canada. Tariffs of 25%, if actually imposed, would be costly for buyers and the industry.
item.content:encoded:
The auto industry has built a North American supply chain that ping-pongs parts between the U.S., Mexico and Canada. Tariffs of 25%, if actually imposed, would be costly for buyers and the industry.

(Image credit: JEFF KOWALSKY)
item.dc:creator: Camila Domonoske

item.title: Navy SEAL was unqualified to lead Tufts lacrosse workout, report finds
item.description: The university will change its approval process for team trainings, among other recommended remedies, after the group workout that left lacrosse players hospitalized in September.
item.content:encoded:
The university will change its approval process for team trainings, among other recommended remedies, after the group workout that left lacrosse players hospitalized in September.

(Image credit: Michael Casey)
item.dc:creator: Manuela López Restrepo
